Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 218,.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 218, Section 21, as the actions giving rise to this Complaint occurred within the jurisdiction of the Boston Municipal Court, Dorchester Division.

Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 186,.proposition: Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 186, Section 14 guarantees tenants the right to quiet enjoyment, which includes the right to have essential services such as heat provided in a habitable condition.

Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 3.raw_text: Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973)
Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 3.proposition: Relevant case law, including Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973) and Tenneco West, Inc. v. Millison, 361 Mass. 160 (1972), establishes that a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment occurs when a landlord fails to provide essential services as required by law.
Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 3.support_reasoning: This separate opinion discusses implying a landlord obligation tied to compliance with housing codes and suggests making the tenant’s rent obligation mutually interdependent with the landlord’s duty to meet those legal standards. However, it is a concurrence/dissent, not the majority holding, and it frames the issue as an implied contractual obligation/warranty based on statutes and codes, not as a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. The excerpt does not establish that failure to provide essential services as required by law constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, so it does not support the proposition as phrased.
Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 3.relevant_excerpt: “As the first step in the removal of the roadblock discussed above I would reverse that rule and hold instead (a) that the various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards, and (b) that by renting such a unit the landlord impliedly agrees with his tenant (i) that at the time of the renting the unit complies with those standards and (ii) that during the term of the renting he will do whatever such legal provisions require him to do for compliance with such standards.”}

Tenneco West, Inc. v. Millison, 361 Mass.raw_text: Tenneco West, Inc. v. Millison, 361 Mass. 160 (1972)
Tenneco West, Inc. v. Millison, 361 Mass.proposition: Relevant case law, including Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973) and Tenneco West, Inc. v. Millison, 361 Mass. 160 (1972), establishes that a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment occurs when a landlord fails to provide essential services as required by law.
Tenneco West, Inc. v. Millison, 361 Mass.case_name: Rowe Contracting Co. v. State Tax Commission
Tenneco West, Inc. v. Millison, 361 Mass.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns sales and use tax exemptions for machinery and supplies used in a stone crushing operation. It does not discuss landlord‑tenant law, covenants of quiet enjoyment, or any duty to provide essential services. Citing this case as authority on breaches of the covenant of quiet enjoyment is therefore inaccurate and unrelated to the proposition stated.
Tenneco West, Inc. v. Millison, 361 Mass.relevant_excerpt: The question for decision is the extent to which the statute (c. 14) exempts from excise the acquisition or use of machinery, machinery parts, and supplies used or consumed in the taxpayer’s stone crushing operations.
